block.p: Weeks
This
On
Week
List
Fiction
THE HOUSE ON HOPE STREET, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A woman with five children must cope with the loss of her husband, who dies on Christmas Day.
OMERTA, by Mario Puzo. (Random House, $25.95.) An F.B.I. agent targets a recently retired Mafia don who has tried to shield his three grown children from the family business.
RIPTIDE, by Catherine Coulter. (Putnam, $23.95.) The senior speechwriter for the governor of New York flees a stalker as well as the police after her boss is shot.
HEARTBREAKER, by Julie Garwood. (Pocket Books, $24.95.) An F.B.I. agent tries to prevent a woman from being killed.
THE INDWELLING, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $22.99.) Volume 7 in a series about true believers who confront the Antichrist after the rapture of the saved. (+)
HOT SIX, by Janet Evanovich. (St. Martin's, $24.95.) A New Jersey bounty hunter searches for her mentor, who is the No. 1 suspect in the killing of an arms dealer's son.
CRADLE AND ALL, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) A former nun turned private eye works on a case involving two virgins who become pregnant.
*THE BRETHREN, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) Three former judges, doing time at a federal prison in Florida, concoct a mail scam that goes awry.
LETHAL SEDUCTION, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) Madison Castelli, a beautiful writer for a magazine in New York, discovers that her father is hiding deadly secrets.
LIAR'S GAME, by Eric Jerome Dickey. (Dutton, $23.95.) A Los Angeles couple's romance is complicated by their exes.
BEFORE I SAY GOOD-BYE, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) A woman with ESP searches for the truth behind the death of her husband.
THE FIGHTING AGENTS, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $25.95.) Volume 4 in a series about the O.S.S. during World War II.
THE BLUEST EYE, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $15.) The story of an 11-year-old black girl -- pregnant by her father -- who prays for her eyes to turn blue.
HOT SPRINGS, by Stephen Hunter. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) In 1946, a former Marine sergeant is hired by an Arkansas prosecutor to wage war on illegal gambling and prostitution.
EASY PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $25.95.) The homicide detective Lucas Davenport investigates a strangulation.
*WHITE TEETH, by Zadie Smith. (Random House, $24.95.) A chronicle of two families, encompassing 150 years, that revolves around an Englishman and a Bengali Muslim.
Weeks
This
On
Week
List
Nonfiction
THE DAY JOHN DIED, by Christopher Andersen. (Morrow, $26.) The events leading up to the plane crash that killed John F. Kennedy Jr., Carolyn Bessette Kennedy and Lauren Bessette.
FLAGS OF OUR FATHERS, by James Bradley with Ron Powers. (Bantam, $24.95.) The story of the six men who raised the flag at Iwo Jima, by the son of one of them.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The author tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
ME TALK PRETTY ONE DAY, by David Sedaris. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) A collection of autobiographical comic essays by the author of ''Naked.''
*IT'S NOT ABOUT THE BIKE, by Lance Armstrong with Sally Jenkins. (Putnam, $24.95.) A memoir by the Tour de France champion and cancer survivor.
FROM DAWN TO DECADENCE, by Jacques Barzun. (HarperCollins, $36.) A survey of 500 years of Western cultural life, from 1500 to the present.
IN A SUNBURNED COUNTRY, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway, $25.) The author of ''A Walk in the Woods'' reports on his travels through Australia.
THE GREATEST GENERATION, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $24.95.) The lives of men and women who came of age during the Depression and World War II.
IN THE HEART OF THE SEA, by Nathaniel Philbrick. (Viking, $24.95.) An account of the whaleship Essex, whose disastrous fate in the early 19th century would inspire Herman Melville.
KITCHEN CONFIDENTIAL, by Anthony Bourdain. (Bloomsbury, $24.95.) A memoir-expose by the executive chef at Brasserie Les Halles in New York.
PAPAL SIN, by Garry Wills. (Doubleday, $25.) A chronicle of what the author sees as the evasions and distortions of the Vatican over the past two centuries.
DUTY, by Bob Greene. (Morrow, $25.) The columnist remembers his father, who was a soldier in World War II, and tells the story of Paul Tibbets, who piloted the Enola Gay.
PAYNE STEWART, by Tracey Stewart with Ken Abraham. (Broadman & Holman, $24.99.) A biography of the golfer who died in a plane crash in 1999, by his widow. (+)
*HOW TO READ AND WHY, by Harold Bloom. (Scribner, $25.) The Sterling professor of humanities at Yale offers instruction in how best to read literary texts.
THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead, $22.95.) What Buddhism and common sense tell us about everyday problems.
Weeks
This
On
Week
List
Children's Books
HARRY POTTER AND THE GOBLET OF FIRE, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/ Scholastic, $25.95.) A British boy takes part in a series of contests against other aspiring wizards. (Ages 10 and up)
HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $17.95.) A British boy finds trouble on his return to a witchcraft school. (Ages 10 and up)
HARRY POTTER AND THE PRISONER OF AZKABAN, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $19.95.) A British boy's life at a school for witchcraft is threatened. (Ages 10 and up)
HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $16.95.) A British boy attends a school for witchcraft. (Ages 10 and up)
BACKSTREET BOYS: The Official Book, by Andre Csillag with the Backstreet Boys. (Delacorte, $14.95.) A photographic scrapbook. (All ages)
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! written and illustrated by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $17.) The problems of finding your way through life. (Ages 8 and up)
BUD, NOT BUDDY, by Christopher Paul Curtis. (Delacorte, $15.95.) A 10-year-old boy in Depression-era Flint, Mich., sets out to find the father he's never seen. (Ages 8 to 12)
THE LITTLE PRINCE, written and illustrated by Antoine de Saint-Exupery. Translated by Richard Howard. (Harcourt, $18.) A poet's new English rendering of the French classic. (All ages)
THE LEGEND OF LUKE, by Brian Jacques. (Philomel, $22.95.) In the 12th volume of a fantasy saga, the story of the first Redwall warrior is told. (Ages 8 and up)
HOW DO DINOSAURS SAY GOOD NIGHT? by Jane Yolen. Illustrated by Mark Teague. (Blue Sky/Scholastic, $15.95.) It's bedtime for dinosaur children. (Ages 3 to 8)
JOSEPH HAD A LITTLE OVERCOAT, written and illustrated by Simms Taback. (Viking, $15.99.) A man transforms his worn-out coat into smaller garments. (Ages 5 to 9)
ELOISE'S GUIDE TO LIFE, by Kay Thompson. Illustrated by Hilary Knight. (Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) How to eat, dress, behave, travel and ''stay 6 forever.'' (All ages)
THE BAD BEGINNING, by Lemony Snicket. (HarperCollins, $8.95.) The three Baudelaire siblings find misfortune everywhere they turn. (Ages 10 and up)

HENRY HIKES TO FITCHBURG, written and illustrated by D. B. Johnson. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.) A tale (inspired by Thoreau) of two friends and the different routes they take to reach their destination. (Ages 4 to 8)
WHAT DADS CAN'T DO, by Douglas Wood. Illustrated by Doug Cushman. (Simon & Schuster, $14.) A child's-eye view of one seemingly helpless father. (Ages 3 to 8)

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending July 15, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+)indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books. Publishers have provided the age designations for their best-selling children's titles.

THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead, $22.95.) What Buddhism and common sense tell us about everyday problems.
